Restorative Yoga & Meditation

It's time to come out of hibernation after a long winter with some restorative and revitalizing yoga and meditation practice. In a restorative class, the goal is to relax but much more can happen during the practice. It’s a very advanced yoga because it is essentially meditation while doing postures. People can be still, release tension and feel how their energy shifts.

 

As you gently guide your body into poses and begin to let go, your mind can focus on the breath. Restorative practice is a bridge to meditation, especially for those who are not drawn to meditation, or who feel challenged just sitting for long periods of time. Restorative yoga can be a doorway between the two, a great segue between active practice and meditative practice.

Have you ever practiced 'trusting that you are exactly where you are meant to be'? Not simply surrendering in a "give up" kind of a way. But, just for a moment, to stop striving be somewhere or something else, and just relax into your situation fully. During this practice, we will coax the mind into becoming clear, peaceful and focused during restorative yoga poses.

This event is being offered for free in celebration of spring! : ) 


After restorative practice, participants will have the option to stay for more vigorous exercise for toning and strength. Also, starting at 10 am, an organic brunch will be served in the cafe with many healthy foods to choose from. The menu is partially raw and is all organic.

 

"The time to relax ...
is when you don't have time for it."
  - Sydney J. Harris
item.why: Restorative yoga is typically known as the yummy practice, the luxurious practice, the one you do every now and then because you need a treat, like having a massage.
